monitor-mysql.name: Connections/ threads connected
monitor-mysql.description: Number of currently open connections

monitor-mysql.name: Connections/ threads cached
monitor-mysql.description: Number of threads in the thread cache

monitor-mysql.name: Connections/ threads running
monitor-mysql.description: Number of threads that are not sleeping

monitor-mysql.name: Connections/ aborted clients
monitor-mysql.description: Number of connection attempts (successful or not) to the MySQL server

monitor-mysql.name: Connections/ aborted connects
monitor-mysql.description: Maximum number of connections that have been in use simultaneously since the server started

monitor-mysql.name: Connections/ attempts
monitor-mysql.description: Number of outstanding connection requests MySQL can have. This comes into play when the main MySQL thread gets very many connection requests in a very short time. It then takes some time (although very little) for the main thread to check the connection and start a new thread. The back_log value indicates how many requests can be stacked during this short time before MySQL momentarily stops answering new requests. You need to increase this only if you expect a large number of connections in a short period of time.

monitor-mysql.name: Connections/ max used
monitor-mysql.description: Number of simultaneous client connections allowed. By default, this is 150, beginning with MySQL 5.1.15. (Previously, the default was 100.)

monitor-mysql.name: Connections/ outstanding connections requests
monitor-mysql.description: Maximum number of simultaneous connections allowed to any given MySQL account. A value of 0 means “no limit.”

monitor-mysql.name: Connections/ max allowed
monitor-mysql.description: How many threads the server should cache for reuse. When a client disconnects, the client threads are put in the cache if there are fewer than thread_cache_size threads there. Requests for threads are satisfied by reusing threads taken from the cache if possible, and only when the cache is empty is a new thread created. This variable can be increased to improve performance if you have a lot of new connections. (Normally, this does not provide a notable performance improvement if you have a good thread implementation.)

monitor-mysql.name: Connections/ max allowed per user
monitor-mysql.description: Number of connections aborted (client died without closing the connection properly) per second to the MySQL server

monitor-mysql.name: Connections/ max threads cached
monitor-mysql.description: Number of failed connections per second to the MySQL server

monitor-mysql.name: IO Requests/ bytes received
monitor-mysql.description: Number of bytes received from all clients

monitor-mysql.name: IO Requests/ bytes sent
monitor-mysql.description: Number of bytes sent to all clients

monitor-mysql.name: IO Requests/ open files
monitor-mysql.description: Number of files that are open

monitor-mysql.name: Select Rates/ select full join
monitor-mysql.description: Number of joins that perform table scans because they do not use indexes. If this value is not 0, you should carefully check the indexes of your tables.

monitor-mysql.name: Select Rates/ select full range join
monitor-mysql.description: Number of joins that used a range search on a reference table

monitor-mysql.name: Select Rates/ select range
monitor-mysql.description: Number of joins that used ranges on the first table. This is normally not a critical issue even if the value is quite large.

monitor-mysql.name: Select Rates/ select range check
monitor-mysql.description: Number of joins without keys that check for key usage after each row. If this is not 0, you should carefully check the indexes of your tables.

monitor-mysql.name: Select Rates/ select scan
monitor-mysql.description: Number of joins that did a full scan of the first table

monitor-mysql.name: Read Rates/ handler read first
monitor-mysql.description: Number of times the first entry was read from an index. If this value is high, it suggests that the server is doing a lot of full index scans; for example, SELECT col1 FROM foo, assuming that col1 is indexed.

monitor-mysql.name: Read Rates/ handler read key
monitor-mysql.description: Number of requests to read a row based on a key. If this value is high, it is a good indication that your tables are properly indexed for your queries.

monitor-mysql.name: Read Rates/ handler read next
monitor-mysql.description: Number of requests to read the next row in key order. This value is incremented if you are querying an index column with a range constraint or if you are doing an index scan.

monitor-mysql.name: Read Rates/ handler read previous
monitor-mysql.description: Number of requests to read the previous row in key order. This read method is mainly used to optimize ORDER BY ... DESC.

monitor-mysql.name: Read Rates/ handler read random
monitor-mysql.description: Number of requests to read a row based on a fixed position. This value is high if you are doing a lot of queries that require sorting of the result. You probably have a lot of queries that require MySQL to scan entire tables or you have joins that do not use keys properly.

monitor-mysql.name: Read Rates/ handler read random next
monitor-mysql.description: Number of requests to read the next row in the data file. This value is high if you are doing a lot of table scans. Generally this suggests that your tables are not properly indexed or that your queries are not written to take advantage of the indexes you have.

monitor-mysql.name: Key Rates/ key blocks not flushed
monitor-mysql.description: Number of key blocks in the key cache that have changed but have not yet been flushed to disk

monitor-mysql.name: Key Rates/ key blocks unused
monitor-mysql.description: Number of unused blocks in the key cache. You can use this value to determine how much of the key cache is in use.

monitor-mysql.name: Key Rates/ key blocks used
monitor-mysql.description: Number of used blocks in the key cache. This value is a high-water mark that indicates the maximum number of blocks that have ever been in use at one time.

monitor-mysql.name: Key Rates/ key read requests (cache)
monitor-mysql.description: Number of requests to read a key block from the cache

monitor-mysql.name: Key Rates/ key reads (disk)
monitor-mysql.description: Number of physical reads of a key block from disk. If Key_reads is large, then your key_buffer_size value is probably too small.

monitor-mysql.name: Key Rates/ key write requests (cache)
monitor-mysql.description: Number of requests to write a key block to the cache

monitor-mysql.name: Key Rates/ key writes (disk)
monitor-mysql.description: Number of physical writes of a key block to disk

monitor-mysql.name: Commands Rates/ flush commands
monitor-mysql.description: Number of executed FLUSH statements

monitor-mysql.name: Commands Rates/ handler commit
monitor-mysql.description: Number of internal COMMIT statements

monitor-mysql.name: Commands Rates/ handler delete
monitor-mysql.description: Number of times that rows have been deleted from tables

monitor-mysql.name: Commands Rates/ handler rollback
monitor-mysql.description: Number of requests for a storage engine to perform a rollback operation

monitor-mysql.name: Commands Rates/ handler savepoint
monitor-mysql.description: Number of requests for a storage engine to place a savepoint

monitor-mysql.name: Commands Rates/ handler savepoint rollback
monitor-mysql.description: Number of requests for a storage engine to roll back to a savepoint

monitor-mysql.name: Commands Rates/ handler update
monitor-mysql.description: Number of requests to update a row in a table

monitor-mysql.name: Commands Rates/ handler write
monitor-mysql.description: Number of requests to insert a row in a table

monitor-mysql.name: Query Cache/ query cache free blocks
monitor-mysql.description: Number of free memory blocks in the query cache

monitor-mysql.name: Query Cache/ query cache free memory
monitor-mysql.description: Amount of free memory for the query cache

monitor-mysql.name: Query Cache/ query cache hits
monitor-mysql.description: Number of query cache hits

monitor-mysql.name: Query Cache/ query cache inserts
monitor-mysql.description: Number of queries added to the query cache

monitor-mysql.name: Query Cache/ query cache low memory prunes
monitor-mysql.description: Number of queries that were deleted from the query cache because of low memory

monitor-mysql.name: Query Cache/ not cached queries
monitor-mysql.description: Number of non-cached queries (not cacheable, or not cached due to the query_cache_type setting)

monitor-mysql.name: Query Cache/ cached queries
monitor-mysql.description: Number of queries registered in the query cache

monitor-mysql.name: Query Cache/ total blocks
monitor-mysql.description: Total number of blocks in the query cache

monitor-mysql.name: Tables/ open tables
monitor-mysql.description: Number of tables that are open

monitor-mysql.name: Tables/ opened tables
monitor-mysql.description: Number of tables that have been opened. If Opened_tables is big, your table_open_cache value is probably too small.

monitor-mysql.name: Tables/ table locks immediate
monitor-mysql.description: Number of times that a table lock was acquired immediately

monitor-mysql.name: Tables/ table locks waited
monitor-mysql.description: Number of times that a table lock could not be acquired immediately and a wait was needed. If this is high and you have performance problems, you should first optimize your queries, and then either split your table or tables or use replication.

monitor-mysql.name: Tables/ table open cache
monitor-mysql.description: Number of open tables for all threads. Increasing this value increases the number of file descriptors that mysqld requires.

monitor-mysql.name: Tables/ max heap table size
monitor-mysql.description: This variable sets the maximum size to which MEMORY tables are allowed to grow. The value of the variable is used to calculate MEMORY table MAX_ROWS values. Setting this variable has no effect on any existing MEMORY table, unless the table is re-created with a statement such as CREATE TABLE or altered with ALTER TABLE or TRUNCATE TABLE.

monitor-mysql.name: Memory/ binlog cache size
monitor-mysql.description: Size of the cache to hold the SQL statements for the binary log during a transaction. A binary log cache is allocated for each client if the server supports any transactional storage engines and if the server has the binary log enabled (--log-bin option). If you often use large, multiple-statement transactions, you can increase this cache size to get more performance.

monitor-mysql.name: Memory/ bulk insert buffer size
monitor-mysql.description: MyISAM uses a special tree-like cache to make bulk inserts faster for INSERT ... SELECT, INSERT ... VALUES (...), (...), ..., and LOAD DATA INFILE when adding data to non-empty tables. This variable limits the size of the cache tree in bytes per thread. Setting it to 0 disables this optimization. The default value is 8MB.

monitor-mysql.name: Memory/ join buffer size
monitor-mysql.description: Size of the buffer that is used for joins that do not use indexes and thus perform full table scans. Normally, the best way to get fast joins is to add indexes. Increase the value of join_buffer_size to get a faster full join when adding indexes is not possible. One join buffer is allocated for each full join between two tables. For a complex join between several tables for which indexes are not used, multiple join buffers may be necessary.

monitor-mysql.name: Memory/ key buffer size
monitor-mysql.description: Index blocks for MyISAM tables are buffered and are shared by all threads. key_buffer_size is the size of the buffer used for index blocks. The key buffer is also known as the key cache. Maximum allowable setting for key_buffer_size is 4GB. The effective maximum size may be less, depending on your available physical RAM and per-process RAM limits imposed by your operating system or hardware platform. Increase the value to get better index handling (for all reads and multiple writes) to as much as you can afford. Using a value that is 25% of total memory on a machine that mainly runs MySQL is quite common. However, if you make the value too large (for example, more than 50% of your total memory) your system may start to page and become extremely slow. MySQL relies on the operating system to perform file system caching for data reads, so you must leave some room for the file system cache.

monitor-mysql.name: Memory/ % key buffer size
monitor-mysql.description: If a write to the binary log causes the current log file size to exceed the value of this variable, the server rotates the binary logs (closes the current file and opens the next one). You cannot set this variable to more than 1GB or to less than 4096 bytes. The default value is 1GB. A transaction is written in one chunk to the binary log, so it is never split between several binary logs.

monitor-mysql.name: Memory/ max binlog size
monitor-mysql.description: Size of the buffer that is allocated when preloading indexes

monitor-mysql.name: Memory/ preload buffer size
monitor-mysql.description: Allocation size of memory blocks that are allocated for objects created during statement parsing and execution. If you have problems with memory fragmentation, it may help to increase this a bit.

monitor-mysql.name: Memory/ query alloc block size
monitor-mysql.description: Each thread that does a sequential scan allocates a buffer of this size (in bytes) for each table it scans. If you do many sequential scans, you may want to increase this value, which defaults to 131072.

monitor-mysql.name: Memory/ read buffer size
monitor-mysql.description: When reading rows in sorted order following a key-sorting operation, the rows are read through this buffer to avoid disk seeks. Setting the variable to a large value can improve ORDER BY performance by a lot. However, this is a buffer allocated for each client, so you should not set the global variable to a large value. Instead, change the session variable only from within those clients that need to run large queries.

monitor-mysql.name: Memory/ read random buffer size
monitor-mysql.description: Each thread that needs to do a sort allocates a buffer of this size. Increase this value for faster ORDER BY or GROUP BY operations.

monitor-mysql.name: Memory/ sort buffer size
monitor-mysql.description: Amount in bytes by which to increase a per-transaction memory pool which needs memory

monitor-mysql.name: Memory/ transaction alloc block size
monitor-mysql.description: There is a per-transaction memory pool from which various transaction-related allocations take memory. The initial size of the pool in bytes is transaction_prealloc_size. For every allocation that cannot be satisfied from the pool because it has insufficient memory available, the pool is increased by transaction_alloc_block_size bytes. When the transaction ends, the pool is truncated to transaction_prealloc_size bytes.

monitor-mysql.name: Memory/ transaction prealloc size
monitor-mysql.description: Percentage of the index block buffer used. Warning: this value is an approximation because some space in the key buffer is be allocated internally for administrative structures.

monitor-mysql.name: Misc./ slow queries
monitor-mysql.description: Number of queries that have taken more than long_query_time seconds

monitor-mysql.name: Misc./ long query time
monitor-mysql.description: If a query takes longer than this many seconds, the server increments the Slow_queries status variable. If you are using the --log-slow-queries option, the query is logged to the slow query log file. This value is measured in real time, not CPU time, so a query that is under the threshold on a lightly loaded system may be above the threshold on a heavily loaded one. The minimum value is 1. The default is 10.

monitor-mysql.name: Misc./ slow launch threads
monitor-mysql.description: Number of threads that have taken more than slow_launch_time seconds to create

monitor-mysql.name: Misc./ slow launch time
monitor-mysql.description: If creating a thread takes longer than this many seconds, the server increments the Slow_launch_threads status variable

monitor-mysql.name: Misc./ sort merge passes
monitor-mysql.description: Number of merge passes that the sort algorithm has had to do. If this value is large, you should consider increasing the value of the sort_buffer_size system variable.

monitor-mysql.name: Misc./ sort rows
monitor-mysql.description: Number of sorted rows

monitor-mysql.name: Misc./ sort scan
monitor-mysql.description: Number of sorts that were done by scanning the table

monitor-mysql.name: Misc./ not flushed delayed rows
monitor-mysql.description: Number of rows waiting to be written in INSERT DELAY queues

monitor-mysql.name: Description/ Database Version
monitor-mysql.description: Version of the MySQL database

threshold-comment.threshold-content: High number of aborted connections
Nombre élevé de connexions interrompues
High number of failed connections
Nombre élevé de connexions échouées
High number of joins without index
Nombre élevé de jointures sans index
High number of joins without index
Nombre élevé de jointures sans index
High number of table locks waited
Nombre élevé d'attentes de lock sur une table
High number of table locks waited
Nombre élevé d'attentes de lock sur une table
High usage of the buffer containing indexes blocks
Pourcentage élevé d'utilisation du buffer contenant les blocs d'indexes
High usage of the buffer containing indexes blocks
Pourcentage élevé d'utilisation du buffer contenant les blocs d'indexes
High number of queries that have taken more than long_query_time seconds to be executed
Nombre élevé de requêtes ayant pris plus de long_query_time secondes pour s'exécuter
High number of merge passes executed by sort algorithm
Nombre élevé de 'merges passes' faites par l'algorithme de tri
